awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2023 Privacy Enhancing Technologies Symposium (PETS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Privacy Enhancing Technology Symposium (PETS), established in 2000, brings together privacy and anonymity experts from around the world to discuss recent advances and new perspectives. PETS addresses the design and realization of privacy services for the Internet and other data systems and communication networks. The 2023 edition of PETS is a hybrid event with a physical gathering held in Lausanne, Switzerland and a concurrent virtual event, from July 10–15, 2023.

The conference presents a valuable opportunity for researchers to share their results and learn about the state of the art in privacy research. It also offers Ph.D. and MS research students a unique platform to learn the recent advances in this area and encourages them to take new initiatives, form new collaborations, and produce additional results.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The travel grant supported US-based students in attending the 23rd Privacy Enhancing Technologies Symposium (PETS 2023), held in Lausanne, Switzerland from July 10 to July 15, 2023. PETS is a premier venue that addresses the design and realization of privacy services for the Internet, data systems, and communication networks by bringing together anonymity and privacy experts from around the world to discuss recent advances in privacy and new perspectives on the field.

The support requested in this proposal enabled 19 US-based students from 13 different institutions to participate in PETS 2023. Students were selected based on their potential contributions to the privacy research community, with priority given to underrepresented groups and those with accepted papers at the symposium. The grant significantly broadened the participation and representation of students at the event, with more than half of the recipients being females or from underrepresented minorities. The funding was used to partially cover recipients' travel-related expenses, such as airfare, hotel, train, taxi, and shuttle services.

The travel grants provided recipients with opportunities to receive feedback on their research, engage in presentations on cutting-edge privacy research, and network with senior researchers and peers in the field of privacy. Recipients reported positive experiences, highlighting the valuable insights and connections gained at PETS 2023.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/03/2024
Modified by: Yidan Hu
